notes.title: Introduction to Public Health
notes.content:
Public health is the science and art of preventing disease, prolonging life, and promoting health through the organized efforts of society.

**Key Principles:**
• Prevention is better than cure
• Health promotion for entire populations
• Evidence-based interventions
• Health equity and social justice

**Core Functions:**
1. Assessment of population health status
2. Policy development
3. Assurance of health services

**Determinants of Health:**
• Social and economic environment
• Physical environment
• Individual characteristics and behaviors
• Health services

notes.title: Epidemiology Basics
notes.content:
Epidemiology is the study of how diseases spread and can be controlled in populations.

**Types of Studies:**
• Descriptive studies (what, when, where, who)
• Analytical studies (why and how)
• Experimental studies (interventions)

**Disease Transmission:**
1. **Direct transmission:** Person to person contact
2. **Indirect transmission:** Through vectors, vehicles, or airborne

**Prevention Levels:**
• **Primary:** Preventing disease occurrence
• **Secondary:** Early detection and treatment
• **Tertiary:** Managing complications

**Important Terms:**
• Incidence: New cases in a time period
• Prevalence: Total cases at a point in time
• Mortality rate: Deaths per population
• Morbidity: Illness in a population

notes.title: Basic Sanitation Principles
notes.content:
Sanitation refers to the provision of facilities and services for the safe disposal of human urine and feces.

**Key Components:**
1. **Excreta Management**
   • Safe collection and disposal
   • Treatment of sewage
   • Prevention of contamination

2. **Solid Waste Management**
   • Collection and segregation
   • Treatment and disposal
   • Recycling and composting

3. **Wastewater Management**
   • Collection systems
   • Treatment processes
   • Safe disposal methods

**Sanitation Chain:**
Capture → Containment → Transport → Treatment → Safe End Use/Disposal

**Health Benefits:**
• Reduces diarrheal diseases
• Prevents cholera and typhoid
• Improves nutrition
• Enhances dignity and safety

notes.title: Waste Management Systems
notes.content:
Effective waste management is crucial for maintaining public health and environmental quality.

**Types of Waste:**
1. **Municipal Solid Waste (MSW)**
   • Household waste
   • Commercial waste
   • Institutional waste

2. **Hazardous Waste**
   • Medical waste
   • Chemical waste
   • Electronic waste

**Waste Management Hierarchy:**
1. **Reduce:** Minimize waste generation
2. **Reuse:** Use items multiple times
3. **Recycle:** Process materials for new products
4. **Recovery:** Energy recovery from waste
5. **Disposal:** Safe final disposal

**Collection Methods:**
• Door-to-door collection
• Community bins
• Transfer stations
• Segregation at source

**Treatment Technologies:**
• Composting (organic waste)
• Incineration (with energy recovery)
• Landfilling (properly engineered)
• Anaerobic digestion

notes.title: Water Quality Standards
notes.content:
Water quality standards ensure that water is safe for intended uses including drinking, bathing, and irrigation.

**Physical Parameters:**
• **Turbidity:** < 1 NTU (Drinking water)
• **Color:** < 15 TCU
• **Odor and Taste:** Acceptable
• **Temperature:** Ambient ± 3°C

**Chemical Parameters:**
• **pH:** 6.5 - 8.5
• **Total Dissolved Solids (TDS):** < 500 mg/L
• **Chloride:** < 250 mg/L
• **Fluoride:** 0.6 - 1.2 mg/L
• **Iron:** < 0.3 mg/L
• **Nitrate:** < 45 mg/L

**Biological Parameters:**
• **Total Coliform:** 0 CFU/100mL
• **E. coli:** 0 CFU/100mL
• **Total Plate Count:** < 500 CFU/mL

**Heavy Metals:**
• **Arsenic:** < 0.01 mg/L
• **Lead:** < 0.01 mg/L
• **Mercury:** < 0.001 mg/L
• **Cadmium:** < 0.003 mg/L

notes.title: Water Treatment Methods
notes.content:
Water treatment removes contaminants to make water suitable for specific uses.

**Conventional Treatment Process:**

1. **Screening:** Remove large debris
2. **Coagulation:** Add chemicals to bind particles
3. **Flocculation:** Gentle mixing for particle aggregation
4. **Sedimentation:** Allow particles to settle
5. **Filtration:** Remove remaining particles
6. **Disinfection:** Kill pathogens

**Disinfection Methods:**
• **Chlorination:** Most common, effective against bacteria and viruses
• **UV Treatment:** No chemical residuals, effective against all pathogens
• **Ozonation:** Strong oxidant, no harmful byproducts
• **Boiling:** Simple household method

**Advanced Treatment:**
• **Reverse Osmosis:** Removes dissolved salts
• **Ion Exchange:** Removes specific ions
• **Activated Carbon:** Removes organic compounds
• **Membrane Filtration:** Various pore sizes

**Household Treatment:**
• Boiling (most reliable)
• Water purification tablets
• Solar disinfection (SODIS)
• Ceramic filters

notes.title: Food Safety Fundamentals
notes.content:
Food safety ensures that food is safe for consumption and free from contamination.

**Foodborne Illnesses:**
• **Bacterial:** Salmonella, E. coli, Campylobacter
• **Viral:** Norovirus, Hepatitis A
• **Parasitic:** Giardia, Cryptosporidium
• **Chemical:** Pesticides, heavy metals

**Sources of Contamination:**
1. **Primary:** During production (farms, processing)
2. **Secondary:** During handling, storage, preparation
3. **Cross-contamination:** Transfer between foods

**HACCP Principles:**
1. Conduct hazard analysis
2. Determine Critical Control Points (CCPs)
3. Establish critical limits
4. Establish monitoring procedures
5. Establish corrective actions
6. Establish verification procedures
7. Establish record keeping

**Temperature Control:**
• **Danger Zone:** 5°C - 60°C (bacteria multiply rapidly)
• **Cold Storage:** < 4°C
• **Hot Holding:** > 60°C
• **Cooking Temperatures:** Vary by food type

**Personal Hygiene:**
• Regular handwashing
• Clean clothing and aprons
• Hair restraints
• No jewelry
• Health monitoring

notes.title: Environmental Health Overview
notes.content:
Environmental health addresses physical, chemical, and biological factors that affect human health.

**Key Areas:**

1. **Air Quality**
   • Ambient air pollution
   • Indoor air quality
   • Occupational exposure

2. **Water Resources**
   • Surface water protection
   • Groundwater management
   • Watershed protection

3. **Soil Contamination**
   • Industrial pollutants
   • Agricultural chemicals
   • Heavy metals

4. **Waste Management**
   • Municipal solid waste
   • Hazardous waste
   • Electronic waste

**Health Impact Assessment:**
• Identify environmental hazards
• Assess exposure pathways
• Evaluate health risks
• Recommend mitigation measures

**Environmental Monitoring:**
• Regular sampling and testing
• Quality assurance protocols
• Data analysis and reporting
• Public health recommendations

**Climate Change Impacts:**
• Heat-related illnesses
• Vector-borne diseases
• Water scarcity
• Food security
• Extreme weather events
